title: Walter Poenisch
text:
Walter Poenisch (July 11, 1913 – June 6, 2000) was an American <a href="baker">baker</a> and <a href="long-distance%20swimming">long-distance swimmer</a>. In 1963, at the age of 50, Poenisch began his professional swimming career by swimming in the Jim Moran Lake Michigan Swim, a 30-mile professional marathon swim in <a href="Lake%20Michigan">Lake Michigan</a>. In June 1972, Poenisch tried to establish a long-distance ocean swimming record off of Florida but was pulled from the water after sharks attacked his safety cage. In 1976, he swam 125 miles in the <a href="Florida%20Straits">Florida Straits</a> and was listed in the <a href="Guinness%20Book%20of%20World%20Records">Guinness Book of World Records</a> for the longest ocean swim. To memorialize his 65th birthday in 1978, Poenisch set out to be the first to swim from <a href="Havana%2C%20Cuba">Havana, Cuba</a> to the <a href="Florida%20Keys">Florida Keys</a>. As then-<a href="President%20of%20Cuba">President of Cuba</a> <a href="Fidel%20Castro">Fidel Castro</a> watched, Poenisch began his swim from Cuba on July 13, 1978. About thirty-three hours later, Poenisch arrived at <a href="Little%20Duck%20Key">Little Duck Key</a>, a small island in the lower Florida Keys. As a result of not filing for official recognition – he had no outside observer beside his own personal crew – his swim did not receive official recognition. He subsequently sued three parties, including the <a href="International%20Swimming%20Hall%20of%20Fame">International Swimming Hall of Fame</a> and <a href="Diana%20Nyad">Diana Nyad</a>, a long-distance swimmer competitor who began her first <a href="Marathon%20swimming%23Solo%20Swims">Cuba-to-Florida swim</a> on July 16, 1978 – two days after Poenisch arrived in Florida. Poenisch claimed that Nyad's publicist and Nyad had <a href="slander">slander</a>ed him just before she left on her swim due to how they characterized his Cuba-to-Florida swim efforts. Poenisch received $5,000 from each of the three parties in an out-of-court settlement five years later in April 1983. Poenisch died in June 2000 and, as of September 2013, has not received official recognition for his 1978 Cuba-to-Florida swim.
In August 2017, Poenisch was inducted into the International Swimming Hall of Fame as a "Pioneer Open Water Swimmer."
